description: {"blocks":[{"key":"6mpil","text":"Here, we present a method for measuring biogenic silica from plankton. Biogenic silica is digested using a wet-alkaline method, in which 2 M sodium carbonate is used to hydrate and depolymerize amorphous silica, resulting in the production of monosilicic acid. The molybdate measurement technique is based on the method described by Shemesh et al. (1988) and follows the JGOFS protocols outlined by UNESCO (1994).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a3h6e","text":"To ensure the accuracy of the measurement, Celite S diatomaceous earth is used as a check standard for the recovery of biogenic silica. Our method yields a recovery rate of 85% to 90%.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"sg3p","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"eljl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"88mn2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"lgmr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"authors":"Shemesh, Aldo; Mortlock, Richard A; Smith, R J; Froelich, Philip N","can_edit":1,"date":598579200,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.1016/0304-4203(88)90113-2","guid":"4962E651341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","journal":"Marine Chemistry","protocol_id":null,"title":"Determination of Ge/Si in marine siliceous microfossils: separation, cleaning and dissolution of diatoms and radiolaria"}}}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"arbjq","text":"Estimation:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7r3le","text":"The low limit of detection is approximately 0.6 uM silicate in the molybdate method. For siliceous plankton, sample requires no less than 4 ug PON (particulate organic nitrogen) per filter when using a 50 mL volumetric flask, or 2 ug PON per filter when using a 25 mL volumetric flask. The sampling volume for biogenic silica samples is approximately 10% of the PON sample volume. For seawater samples, the sampling volume for biogenic silica samples should be determined based on the community composition.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8nq4b","text":"Switch to a 100 uL pipette, add 100 uL at a time. Near the equivalence point, when the colour starts to change to pink more markedly but after mixing the orange colour returns, it is necessary to add HCl drop by drop. The first drop that causes a permanent colour change to pink determines the equivalence point. Stop adding HCl. Cap the tube, hold tube horizontally, gently invert the tube to wash residue at the inner side of the cap down to the solution. The color may change back to orange, add more drops of HCl until the color turns to permanent pink again (See the color of the left tube).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":204,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"qh6co","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"afg9n","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3bvtr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5c8cj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"93F6C7A6345511EEAFD10A58A9FEAC02","height":275.6672727272728,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"image/jpeg","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"20230210_125451.jpg","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k2xr8uue.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k2xj8uue.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/k2xq8uue.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/k2xf8uue.webp","width":206.84447476125513}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"91ejn","text":"We have found that the optimal pH for the reaction between silicate and molybdate to form silicomolybdic acid is 3 to 4.
